questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with complaints of dizziness. On examination, pallor was present. She will be considered severely anemic if her hemoglobin is less than _____.
questions.solution:
Severe anemia is defined as Hb < 7 g/dL.

Anemia in pregnancy is said to occur when Hb level is <11 g/dL. It is classified as shown below:

Hemoglobin values (g/dL)  WHO classification of anemia in pregnancy ICMR classification of anemia in pregnancy
≥11

Normal

In the second trimester, Hb ≥10.5 g/dL is considered normal

 Normal
10-10.9 Mild  Mild
7-9.9  Moderate Moderate
<7  Severe Severe
<4   - Very severe

questions.text: Which of the following is the second most common pathological cause of anemia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The second most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is anemia associated with chronic disease. The most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is iron deficiency anemia. 

Women with chronic disorders may develop anemia for the first time during pregnancy. Causes include:

  • Chronic renal insufficiency - the most common cause. Recombinant erythropoietin is used for treating anemia due to chronic renal failure.
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Granulomatous infections
  • Malignant neoplasms
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Chronic suppurative conditions.

Note: The most common cause of anemia in pregnancy is physiological. It is normally seen during pregnancy. This occurs due to the expansion of plasma volume by 30–40%. This increase is much more than the increase in red cell mass (20-30%) during pregnancy. This leads to hemodilution and an apparent decrease in hemoglobin levels.

questions.text: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.

Iron requirement during pregnancy
Fetus and placenta 300 mg
Expansion of maternal hemoglobin mass 500 mg
Losses through normal excretion routes 200 mg
Total 1000 mg

The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.

Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.

questions.text: You initiate iron and folic acid supplements for a woman at 13 weeks of gestation. According to the ministry of health & family welfare (MoHFW), what is the minimum duration for which she should take these supplements?
questions.solution:
The guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid daily for at least 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy, and to be continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must be continued until 180 days postpartum.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy is continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days). It should also be continued for 180 days post-partum.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red color

 Daily  Red 

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched dose for folic acid supplementation that should be given in pregnant women with the following conditions?

choices.text: Previous child with neural tube defect - 1 mg

questions.solution:
The amount of folic acid to be given to pregnant women suffering from sickle cell anemia is 5 mg.

This is to reduce the risk of neural tube defects and to compensate for the increased demand for folate during pregnancy.

Normally in all sickle cell patients (irrespective of age or sex), 1mg of folic acid is given to prevent folate deficiency.

Note: William's Obstetrics 26th Edition mentions folic acid 4 mg daily for pregnant women with sickle cell disease. However various other sources and RCOG guidelines mention it as 5 mg daily. Hence this is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Folic Acid in Pregnancy

Condition Daily dosage of folic acid
Prophylaxis - to prevent neural tube defects (NTDs)

400 mcg (WHO)

500 mcg (MoHFW- India)
Treatment of folic acid deficiency

800 mcg (WHO)

1 mg (MoHFW-India)
Previous child with NTD

5 mg* (WHO)

4 mg (NCBI)

5 mg (MoHFW-India)
Sickle cell disease 5 mg 
Thalassemia 5 mg
Epilepsy 4 mg

WHO: World Health Organization

MoHFW-India: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

*more acceptable (most references)

Controversial: Latest ACOG guidelines mention 0.4mg of folic acid to be given to epileptic pregnant women / pregnant women on ASM (Anti-seizure medications).
Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition and Harrison's Medicine 21st edition mention the dose to be 4mg per day.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women.

This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 μg/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.

However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 μg/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.

Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A pregnant teacher presented with complaints of difficulty concentrating at work. Investigations revealed normal MCV with blood picture as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiency anemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia.

Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia:

  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  • Typical photo pencil cells
  • Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes)

Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia:

  • Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest change
  • Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text: A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. He mentioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and ice cream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion. 

If anemia is diagnosed:

  • In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred
  • In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls <8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml
  • In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred

Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose.

Other iron preparations include:

  • Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate 
  • IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose
  • IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose
  • Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed for postpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.

Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).

It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.

questions.text: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation. What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?
questions.solution:
The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:

Total dose in mg =  2.4 X (Target Hb - Actual Hb) X Body Wt. + 500 mg

  • 2.4 - conversion factor
  • Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve 
  • Actual Hb- level of current Hb
  • 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores

Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women?

choices.text: Can be given in first trimester
Sensitivity test is mandatory before administration
Can be given alongside oral iron therapy

questions.solution:
Parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is avoided if the patient has a history of chronic liver disease.

It is used as an alternative therapy in people who cannot tolerate oral iron. 

Contraindications include:

  • A history of prior anaphylactic reaction to parenteral iron therapy
  • First trimester of pregnancy - there is no evidence on the use of IV iron in the first trimester of pregnancy
  • Chronic liver disease
  • Active infection (acute or chronic)

A sensitivity test prior to the infusion is not mandatory. IV iron should be given with caution even if previous administrations have been well tolerated.

Oral iron should be stopped at least 24 hours prior to therapy to avoid iron toxicity.

questions.text: A G3P2 female patient who is an agricultural laborer presents with complaints of fatigue at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, pallor and mild pedal edema are present. Her hemoglobin is 6.7 g/dl. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for severe anemia (< 7g/dL) in the third trimester is packed cell transfusion. It is preferred over whole blood as it avoids volume overload.

Indications of blood transfusion in pregnancy include:

  • Pregnancy <34 weeks 
    • Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
    • Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
  • Pregnancy >34 weeks - Hb <7 g/dL.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was brought by her husband after fainting at home. He gave a history of her being clumsy and forgetful over the last few weeks. Investigations revealed high MCV with hypersegmented neutrophils. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: 1000 μg of IM cyanocobalamin + folic acid

questions.solution:
The given scenario points to vitamin B12 deficiency. It is treated by vitamin B12 injections with folic acid supplementation. 1000 μg of IM cyanocobalamin should be given initially every week for 6 weeks, following which it should be given once every month.

Megaloblastic anemia caused by Vit B12 deficiency should be identified and treated accordingly because folic acid supplementation alone will not help.

Causes of Vit B12 deficiency leading to anemia in pregnancy:

  • Gastric resection
  • Addisonian pernicious anemia
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Ileal resection
  • Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel.

questions.text:
An anxious primigravida with sickle cell trait comes to you for her first antenatal checkup. Which of the following is she at a higher risk of developing during the course of this pregnancy?
  1. Pre-eclampsia
  2. Abortions
  3. Urinary tract infections
  4. Placental abruptions
  5. Preterm labor
questions.solution:
Among the given options, patients with sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing urinary tract infections.

Sickle cell disease, on the other hand, is associated with increased risk of :

  • Miscarriages
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Preterm labor
  • Venous thromboembolism
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Placental abruption 
  • Fetal distress in labor

Note: Sickle cell trait is a benign condition in which the affected person has only one abnormal hemoglobin beta gene allele whereas, in sickle cell disease, the affected person has two abnormal hemoglobin beta gene alleles and is hence severely symptomatic. Unlike individuals with sickle cell disease, those with sickle cell trait do not have symptoms related to sickling and mostly lead a normal life.

questions.text: A sexually active woman with sickle cell anemia comes to the clinic for advice regarding contraception. Which of the following is the ideal contraceptive for this patient?
questions.solution:
Low-dose oral progestins or progesterone injections or implants are ideal contraceptives in a patient with sickle cell anemia. Progesterone has been known to prevent painful sickle cell crises.

It is considered very safe in pregnancy. It is rated level 1 indicating that there is no restriction in their use. 

Contraceptive methods and their safety profile in sickle cell anemia:

Level 1 contraceptives (no restriction):

  • Progestogen-only injection (DMPA)
  • Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena)
  • Emergency contraception containing progestins

Level 2 contraceptives (advantages outweigh disadvantages):

  • Combined oral contraceptive
  • Copper intrauterine device.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with thalassemia major presents to the clinic at 24 weeks of gestation with fatigue and shortness of breath. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Parenteral iron therapy is the treatment of choice
Breast feeding is safe after delivery
Repeated transfusions are necessary to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dl

questions.solution:
In thalassemia major, both oral and parenteral iron preparations are avoided. This is because these patients are already in a state of iron overload due to multiple blood transfusions.

Pregnancy in patients with thalassemia major is very rare. In case pregnancy occurs the following strategies are adopted:

  • Iron chelating agents should be stopped
  • 5mg folic acid supplementation should be given daily
  • Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy
  • Repeated blood transfusions are given to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dL
  • Breastfeeding is safe and iron chelation therapy can be resumed post-delivery.
